name: London
intro_vibe: Royal heritage meets modern multicultural energy in this iconic global capital.

general_info.description: London is the capital and largest city of England and the United Kingdom. As one of the world's most influential cities, London has been a major settlement for two millennia. It is a leading global city in arts, commerce, education, entertainment, fashion, finance, healthcare, media, professional services, research and development, tourism, and transportation.

weather_breakdown.name: January
weather_breakdown.clothing: Warm coat, waterproof layers, sturdy boots

weather_breakdown.name: June
weather_breakdown.clothing: Summer clothes + light jacket for evenings

weather_breakdown.name: December
weather_breakdown.clothing: Heavy winter coat, gloves, warm hat

etiquette_tips: Queueing is Sacred: Never cut in line. The queue is a British institution and jumping it is social suicide.
Stand on the Right: On escalators, stand on the right, walk on the left. This is strictly enforced on the Tube.
Mind the Gap: Pay attention to the iconic warning between the train and platform. Also, don't block Tube doors.
Pub Etiquette: Order at the bar (no table service in most pubs). Say 'please' and 'thank you' liberally.
Tipping: 10-15% in restaurants if service not included. Round up in taxis. No tipping in pubs.
Volume: Keep conversations quieter than you might be used to, especially on public transport.

neighborhoods.name: Westminster & South Bank
neighborhoods.description: Home to Big Ben, Parliament, the London Eye, and the Thames riverside walk. Touristy but unmissable for first-timers.

neighborhoods.name: Shoreditch & Brick Lane
neighborhoods.description: Street art, vintage markets, curry houses, and nightlife. The edgy, creative heart of East London.

neighborhoods.name: Notting Hill & Portobello
neighborhoods.description: Pastel townhouses, antique markets, and upscale bohemian vibes. Made famous by the Hugh Grant film.

neighborhoods.name: Covent Garden
neighborhoods.description: Street performers, boutique shops, theaters, and restaurants. Always buzzing with energy day and night.

neighborhoods.name: Camden Town
neighborhoods.description: Punk heritage, sprawling markets, live music venues, and canal-side street food. Unique London character.

neighborhoods.name: South Kensington
neighborhoods.description: Museum quarter with world-class institutions, elegant Victorian architecture, and upscale dining.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: The Tube is your best friend. Get an Oyster Card or use contactless payment.
details: The Tube (London Underground): 11 lines covering the entire city. Avoid peak hours (7:30-9:30am, 5-7pm).
Oyster Card / Contactless: Tap in and out. Daily cap applies (cheaper than buying individual tickets).
Buses: Extensive network, great for sightseeing. No cash accepted - Oyster/contactless only.
Walking: Many central areas are very walkable. Download CityMapper app for best routes.
Black Cabs vs Uber: Black cabs are iconic but pricey. Uber is widely available and cheaper.

logistics.title: Scams to Avoid
logistics.summary: London is generally safe, but watch for ticket touts and overpriced tourist traps.
details: Ticket Touts: Never buy West End theater tickets from street sellers. Use official TKTS booth in Leicester Square.
Unlicensed Taxis: Only use licensed black cabs or pre-booked minicabs (Uber, Bolt, etc.).
Tourist Trap Restaurants: Avoid restaurants in Leicester Square and Piccadilly - overpriced and low quality.
Fake Monks: People dressed as monks asking for 'donations' are scammers. Politely decline.
Oyster Card Scams: Buy your Oyster card only at official Tube stations, not from street vendors.

logistics.title: Safety Basics
logistics.summary: London is very safe, but stay alert for pickpockets in tourist areas.
details: Pickpockets: Active on the Tube, especially on busy lines (Central, Northern) and at tourist spots.
Phone Theft: Don't use your phone near Tube doors - thieves can snatch and run as doors close.
Night Safety: Most areas are safe at night. Avoid unlit parks and deserted streets.
Emergency Number: 999 for police, ambulance, fire. 101 for non-emergencies.
Crossings: Look both ways! Traffic comes from the opposite direction. 'Look Right' painted on roads.

logistics.title: Apps to Download
logistics.summary: These apps will make navigating London much easier.
details: CityMapper: The absolute best for transit navigation. Shows Tube delays, bus times, walking routes.
TfL Go: Official Transport for London app for live updates and journey planning.
Uber / Bolt: Ride-hailing apps. Widely available and reliable.
OpenTable / The Fork: Restaurant reservations. Many places book up quickly.
Trainline: For booking train tickets to other UK cities in advance (much cheaper).

must_eat.description: The quintessential British dish: battered white fish (usually cod or haddock) with thick-cut chips, mushy peas, and tartar sauce. Best enjoyed from a proper chippy, wrapped in paper. Look for places using fresh fish and cooking in beef dripping for authentic flavor.

A Sunday institution: roasted meat (beef, lamb, chicken, or pork) served with roast potatoes, Yorkshire pudding, seasonal vegetables, and rich gravy. Book ahead at traditional pubs - this is a weekly ritual for many Londoners. Served typically from noon to 6pm on Sundays.

The legendary British breakfast: bacon, sausages, eggs, baked beans, grilled tomatoes, mushrooms, black pudding, and toast. Often called a 'fry-up'. Found in cafes and greasy spoons across the city. Perfect hangover cure or hearty start to a day of sightseeing.

An elegant British tradition: finger sandwiches, scones with clotted cream and jam, and delicate pastries, served with tea on a tiered stand. Dress smartly and book in advance at classic hotels like The Ritz, Claridge's, or The Savoy for the full experience.

London's curry scene is world-class, particularly on Brick Lane in East London. Try chicken tikka masala (invented in the UK), lamb rogan josh, or biryani. Many restaurants are BYOB (bring your own alcohol) with no corkage fee, making it affordable and fun.

Traditional East End working-class dish: meat pie (usually minced beef) with mashed potatoes and a thin parsley sauce called 'liquor'. Some shops also serve jellied eels. A taste of old London at historic pie shops like M. Manze or F. Cooke.

A hard or soft-boiled egg wrapped in seasoned sausage meat, coated in breadcrumbs, and deep-fried. A popular pub snack and picnic food. Modern versions get creative with fillings like black pudding or chorizo.

The pub is a cornerstone of British culture. Try a pint of real ale, cider, or a gin and tonic. Many serve excellent food ('gastropubs'). Order at the bar, not table service. Historic pubs like Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese (1667) offer atmospheric charm.

A portable pastry filled with beef, potato, swede (rutabaga), and onion. Originally miner's lunch from Cornwall, now a popular grab-and-go snack across London. Look for authentic Cornish pasties with the protected geographical status crimped edge.

Comfort food classic: sausages ('bangers') served over creamy mashed potatoes with onion gravy. A pub staple across London. Quality varies - look for pubs using premium sausages from local butchers for the best experience.

Beloved British dessert: moist sponge cake made with dates, covered in toffee sauce, and served warm with vanilla custard or ice cream. Rich, sweet, and utterly indulgent. A must-try at traditional pubs and restaurants.

Traditional East End delicacy: chopped eels boiled in stock that sets into a jelly when cooled. An acquired taste and piece of London history. Found at traditional pie and mash shops. Not for everyone, but a cultural experience for the adventurous.

items.description: The iconic clock tower (officially Elizabeth Tower) and the seat of British government. Stunning Gothic Revival architecture on the Thames.
Giant Ferris wheel on the South Bank offering panoramic city views. Book tickets online to skip queues.
London's most famous bridge with distinctive twin towers. Walk across for free or visit the exhibition for glass floor views.
The official residence of the British monarch. Watch the Changing of the Guard ceremony (11am, check schedule online).
Massive collection of world art and artifacts including the Rosetta Stone and Egyptian mummies. Free entry. Allow at least 3 hours.
Stunning Victorian building housing dinosaur skeletons, the blue whale, and vast natural wonders. Free entry. Great for all ages.
Converted power station housing contemporary art. Free entry to permanent collection. Stunning views from the top-floor terrace.
World's leading museum of art, design, and performance. Incredible decorative arts and fashion collections. Free entry.
Medieval fortress housing the Crown Jewels. Nearly 1000 years of history as royal palace, prison, and execution site. Book online.
Gothic church where monarchs are crowned and buried. Stunning architecture and historical significance. Entry fee required.
Christopher Wren's baroque masterpiece with iconic dome. Climb to the Whispering Gallery and Golden Gallery for city views.
Massive central park perfect for picnics, boating on the Serpentine, or visiting the Diana Memorial Fountain. Free entry.
Beautiful royal park with stunning rose gardens, London Zoo, and outdoor theater in summer. More manicured than Hyde Park.
Historic park on a hill with sweeping views of London skyline. Home to Royal Observatory and Prime Meridian line.
Historic food market with gourmet vendors, street food, and fresh produce. Crowded but worth it for foodies. Best Thursday-Saturday.
Famous antiques and vintage market in colorful Notting Hill. Busiest on Saturdays. Explore the area's pastel houses too.
Eclectic market with alternative fashion, crafts, vintage finds, and international street food. Open daily, busiest on weekends.

affiliate_products.title: Universal Travel Adapter (UK Type G)
affiliate_products.reason: UK plugs are unique (three rectangular pins). You absolutely need this adapter - US/EU plugs won't fit anywhere.

affiliate_products.title: Compact Travel Umbrella
affiliate_products.reason: London weather is famously unpredictable. A small umbrella fits in your day bag and saves you from sudden showers.

affiliate_products.title: Waterproof Walking Shoes
affiliate_products.reason: London requires a LOT of walking, and streets can be wet. Comfortable, waterproof shoes are essential for sightseeing.
